posts.name: Danya
posts.cooked:
image 1584×396 38.3 KB

image 1584×396 38.3 KB

image 1584×396 38.3 KB

As one of the teams selected for the first wave of SystemCore alpha testing, we’re excited to share our journey with the future robot controller along with our strategic redesign throughout the 2025 offseason.

We are FRC team 3506 YETI Robotics, a community based team located in Charlotte, North Carolina, formed in 2010. Our team is a part of the Queen City Robotics Alliance (QCRA), a non-profit organization we helped found, that supports Charlotte area FIRST teams.

Currently we are in our off-season after a successful 2025 season where we won the FIRST Impact Award at UNC Asheville and the North Carolina District Championship, along with the Team Sustainability Awards in our division at the FIRST World Championship.

So far we’ve tried to eliminate our use of an OrangePi for vision processing by running Photon Vision on Systemcore, but based on another team’s testing where one camera with a 2D AprilTag pipeline made the CPU usage jump from 25-30% to 65-70%. We decided that our 2 cameras that use 3D pipelines would be smoother on our OrangePi and keep the CPU usage on the main robot controller low.

Just sharing my experience getting PhotonVision running on SystemCore. Installation is very simple, just copy the PhotonVision JAR onto the device and create a systemd service to run it as root. Wi...

More on our SystemCore adventures, we’re planning on testing the necessity of a CANivore. Our team has all the motors and sensors that are a part of our drivetrain on a separate CANbus added by the CANivore to improve speed and control when driving, as well as to protect the drivetrain in case any devices on the main CANbus break. We’d like to test whether or not using a CANivore or 2 CANchains on SystemCore works better. A major problem we faced this season with the roboRIO was CPU usage issues due to vision processing. The SystemCore is much more powerful compared to the roboRIO and we are testing if those issues will be solved with the new robot controller.

A lot of our work with SystemCore as of now is preparing for it to be used on our competition robot for offseason events. As a team, we are focusing on training rookies and undergoing a strategic redesign of our REEFSCAPE robot, Beluga, that incorporates SystemCore and is more competitive for said events.

Keep in mind we won’t have regular updates due to SystemCore not being on the robot yet!

In addition to the electrical changes brought about by SystemCore, we plan to re-wire a lot of the robot for cleaner wire management and as practice for new members of the team. We’ve designed a new end effector for our offseason competitions after many strategic redesign workshops. This end effector is meant to give us both coral and algae capabilities using super-pinch, something we weren’t able to fully utilize during the actual season. We are trying it with a 20:1 gear ratio on the intake rollers for torque to pinch algae.

Intaking ALGAE 1065×855 145 KB Intaking CORAL 749×654 93.3 KB

Intaking ALGAE 1065×855 145 KB

Intaking ALGAE 1065×855 145 KB

Intaking CORAL 749×654 93.3 KB

Intaking CORAL 749×654 93.3 KB

On the programming side of our team, we are rewriting our auto-align code, which is crucial for fast cycles in this game, and creating a simulation sandbox for future robot projects. Simulation is a tool we heavily utilized this season, for anything from camera placements to logic for our game piece manipulator system. We were able to simulate camera feeds using PhotonVision and AdvantageScope’s 3D Field, which greatly sped up our programming process. With a custom 3D model of our robot, we were able to quickly test logic code despite its four degrees of freedom.

Our first offseason event is SCRAP, in Camden, South Carolina on August 23rd. Stay tuned for more updates and please ask questions below!

posts.name: Danya
posts.cooked:
On our competition robot, we use a magnetic limit switch at the bottom of our elevator because we decided not to put CANcoders onto our elevator motors. However, once we made the switch from our RoboRIO 2.0 to SystemCore, we found there was no change in signal when connected to the new robot controller.

MagSwitch setup 1346×1007 189 KB

MagSwitch setup 1346×1007 189 KB

MagSwitch setup 1346×1007 189 KB

We proceeded to test multiple ports, verified the magnet being detected by the switch, verified the signal wire changes voltage with the magnet (3.3V which is within the range on the spec sheet ), and also that the switch works on the RIO with a test board.

Below is the panel showing red and “X” when we tested out the IO by putting in bare wire, shorting the power and ground pins of a port. We fixed this fault with a power cycle. Normally, the red light is off. It only turns on when there is some kind of fault. It’s pretty cool being able to see exactly which port is faulting!

Red IO light :c 1920×2560 400 KB

Red IO light :c 1920×2560 400 KB

Red IO light :c 1920×2560 400 KB

The internal resistor inside SystemCore is a 4.7kΩ pull down resistor compared to a 40kΩ pull up resistor on the RIO. After opening an issue on Github, Thad House confirmed our suspicions that the lack of value changing was very likely due to the pull down resistor. He speculated the sensor was built with a pull up in the signal path, and used an NPN style transistor setup. This problem could be fixed by adding a resistor to the circuit, but we did not have one on hand. This suggests that many of our common powered sensors we have now may not work with the internal pull down resistor.

REV Magnetic Limit Switch not being read on SystemCore Smart I/O ports opened 10:56PM - 16 Aug 25 UTC taran-duba

REV Magnetic Limit Switch not being read on SystemCore Smart I/O ports opened 10:56PM - 16 Aug 25 UTC taran-duba

opened 10:56PM - 16 Aug 25 UTC taran-duba

opened 10:56PM - 16 Aug 25 UTC

taran-duba

Hi all,

We are running a Rev Magnetic limit switch on our robot with SystemCore … and are having an issue with the boolean reading not changing. We’ve tested on multiple ports, verified the mag switch is detecting the magnet, verified the signal wire changes voltage (3.3V) with the magnet, verified it works on the rio with a test board. There’s no change in boolean signal when connected to SystemCore. 

We’ve read here that the internal resistor is a 4.7kOhm pull down resistor in syscore vs a 40kOhm pull up resistor on the rio. when running power to syscore the multimeter reads 3.3 volts. we think this should just mean the value is inverted? but it may be causing this lack of value changing too.

Has anyone experienced this before?

Hi all,

We are running a Rev Magnetic limit switch on our robot with SystemCore … and are having an issue with the boolean reading not changing. We’ve tested on multiple ports, verified the mag switch is detecting the magnet, verified the signal wire changes voltage (3.3V) with the magnet, verified it works on the rio with a test board. There’s no change in boolean signal when connected to SystemCore. 

We’ve read here that the internal resistor is a 4.7kOhm pull down resistor in syscore vs a 40kOhm pull up resistor on the rio. when running power to syscore the multimeter reads 3.3 volts. we think this should just mean the value is inverted? but it may be causing this lack of value changing too.

Has anyone experienced this before?

After asking in the Unofficial FRC Discord, we were told that 3.3V inverters and a 1/8 W 1k pull up resistor or a 3.3V buffer and a pull up resistor would work as a solution. The next hardware version of SystemCore will have a different internal resistor, which may make it more compatible with more existing sensors.

It looks like the digital IOs are configured to pull down, as opposed to the pull-ups on the RIO. Is this subject to change in future iterations of the hardware? Keeping interoperability with the R...

We then replaced the magnetic limit switch with a physical limit switch as a temporary solution since that is just a simple electrical switch. Current temporary setup for competition 1208×901 83.8 KB

Current temporary setup for competition 1208×901 83.8 KB

Current temporary setup for competition 1208×901 83.8 KB

posts.name: Danya
posts.cooked:
We scout at every event we go to and make sure to provide all data publicly on our Github.

Throughout the last year we submitted over 3,000 forms with ~48,000 data points. Our dataset is 100% COMPLETE for the Galileo Division at Worlds, and we also have lots of data from FIRST North Carolina State Championship, FNC District Mecklenburg County Event, and FNC District UNC Asheville Event.

ALL of our past scouting data (not just REEFSCAPE!) is available here:

Roborio’s I2C port has sync issues with rev i2c sensors. Is it working with Systemcore ?

posts.name: Danya
posts.cooked:
We do not use any REV I2C sensors, however the REV control/expansion hub was mentioned in another discussion about SystemCore’s internal resistor. I2C devices are also mentioned in a discussion about SPI functionality. These were just on the SystemCore Github, not sure if it’s what you’re looking for.

It looks like the digital IOs are configured to pull down, as opposed to the pull-ups on the RIO. Is this subject to change in future iterations of the hardware? Keeping interoperability with the R...

I didn't quickly find an answer in the 2027 javadocs so poking here: Do SmartIO or the I2C outputs also support SPI functionality? It's pretty darn low priority for me, and I'd be OK if it didn't e...

posts.name: Danya
posts.cooked:
This allowed us to verify some crucial connections including initializing the autonomous period, A-stopping, initializing the teleoperating period and being able to drive, and finally emergency stopping. The FMS had connected fine in our subsequent matches although there was a network handshake issue at the start of one which didn’t seem to be due to SystemCore.

What fixed the issue was unplugging the ethernet cable from SystemCore and plugging it back in. SCRAP’s FTAs suspected it was simply a network handshake issue that could normally be seen on RIOs and would usually be fixed with the reset button. We know many teams have brought up the lack of a physical reset button as a concern, this FTA had looked for that button when troubleshooting and requested it be brought back on future versions.

posts.name: Bob Bell
posts.cooked: It was so cool to see SystemCore in person – it was much smaller than I had imagined!  Admittedly, we had plenty of our own testing issues going on, so I wasn’t able to learn as much as I would have liked.  I’ll look forward to learning more about your experiences from Yeti members at SCRIW!

posts.name: Danya
posts.cooked: Yeah it’s super compact, we were shocked how much space we saved. We originally had our orange pi housed on top of the RIO  and then the CANivore on top of that, but now they all get to sit nicely on the belly pan.  We’re actually doing a new build for SCRIW based on Rocky so you’ll see that there!

posts.name: David Si
posts.cooked: We have the same Issue, I was working on the systemcore and try to see how the software grabs the Ethernet stuff or even try plug in with usb directly, it shows as linux device and not really reaching it. I don’t think that it isn’t passing but it reads it differently, I think there is some a way to fix it but I don’t know yet. Limelight or other Protonvision did not officially posted about supporting systemcore yet so I was just thinking about using Ni RoboRio 2 instead of systemCore until they have documentation on it.
